newsitem.title: USA: PRESS DIGEST - Wall Street Journal - Feb 3.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Wall Street Journal - Feb 3.

text.p: The following stories were reported in Monday's electronic version of The Wall Street Journal:
* Apple Computer is considering selling some key business units to cut costs amid slower-than-expected sales of its Macintosh computers.
* The U.S. economy expanded at 4.7 percent annually in the 1996 fourth quarter, but the government's broadest gauge of inflation remains at 1.8 percent.
* Pacific Gas & Electric said it will buy the natural gas business of Valero Energy for $722.5 million in stock.
* Mercury Finance faces new demands for larger payments this week after the company failed to repay $17 million of commercial debt last week.
* China and the U.S. agreed to renew a textile trade pact, but this is unlikely to narrow the nearly $40 billion trade deficit the U.S. has with China.

* U.S. auto makers are renewing complaints that the strong dollar is putting them at a disadvantage with Japanese rivals, who are expected to show strong gains in January's light vehicle sales in the U.S.
* ITT Corp rejected an offer from Hilton Hotels to discuss the $6.5 billion unsolicited bid for ITT that Hilton launched last week.

* An investment group that includes Chile's Infisa SA, Chase Manhattan and National Bank of Canada plans to invest $750 million to acquire Latin American financial companies and form a pan-Latin American financial firm.
* DynCorp has won a major military contract sought by Halliburton's Brown & Root unit.
* Scotsman Industries has agreed to buy most of Kysor Industrial for about $300 million.
* Rockwell International is seeking to flood the market with new computer chips to beat rival U.S. Robotics in the high-speed computer modem industry.
* Revised "circuit breakers" to stop panic-driven sell-offs are scheduled to go into effect Monday.
* Coca-Cola reported its fourth quarter net rose 18 percent.
* Faced by allegations of discrimination, Nationwide Insurance Enterprise said it will revise underwriting standards to expand investment in poor urban areas.
* There could be smaller profits for U.S. meatpackers and higher consumer prices as cattle ranchers shrink herds to cut two years of widening losses.
* Nintendo America is competing closely with Sony Computer Entertainment America as the top-selling video game player.
* The chairman of Systems of Excellence was to sentenced to prison amid charges of market manipulation.

* When Seagram's Edgar Bronfman Jr in early 1995 bought control of the blundering MCA entertainment company -- now Universal Studios -- many investors dismissed him as a dilettante movie buff and part-time songwriter, unequal to the exacting world of Hollywood. Seagram's stock dropped like a stone.
But since then, the 41-year-old scion of the Canadian
liquor barons has turned around the MCA music group and revived its theme parks. -- Heard on the Street.
* As if the Fed needed any more help taming inflation, it just got a new tool, one that will likely prove useful to investors as well.
The new tool? The Treasury Department's long-awaited "inflation-indexed" securities that went on sale last Wednesday to a rousing reception from investors. -- Credit Markets.
